Notes: Problematic.  The *bà initial portion appears to be the same as standlone term 我 (wa, “I; we”).  Meanwhile, the -n[u] ending also appears in Old Japanese term unu ("you", pejorative).
Problematic.  The *bà initial portion appears to be the same as standlone term 我 (wa, “I; we”).  Meanwhile, the -n[u] ending also appears in Old Japanese term unu ("you", pejorative).
Distal marker, far from both speaker and listener.  Contrasts with *so as the medial-distance marker, far from speaker but close to listener.
The medial mi is listed in some sources as cognate with the root me ("female")
Problematic.  May be a compound of sira ("white") + mi (possibly "body"?).  The final mi element also appears in 蚤 (nomi, “flea”).
The *tumu root is sometimes described in other sources as an alternation of *tubu, itself a generic root form denoting something round.  See 頭 for further details.

Problematic.  The reconstruction appears to be based on modern verb 与える (ataeru), regarded by other sources as deriving from root form *at- with a sense of "to contact, to come into contact; to fit; to be fitting, to be appropriate".
Incorrect.  Listed in Japanese dictionaries as deriving from a compound of honorific prefix mi- + noun ti "road, path, way".  See 道 for further details.
The *míntórì term originally referred specifically to the color of new sprouts.  The mín- portion appears to be related to the similar reconstructed element in *míntu ("fresh, young, vibrant").

Problematic.  The reconstruction appears to be based on modern adjective stem 暖か (atataka), itself listed in Japanese dictionaries as root atata- + adjective-forming suffix -ka.  The root atata- also appears in the verbs atatamaru ("to warm up", intransitive) and atatameru ("to warm up", transitive).
The root is likely *sàm-, with the -ù- portion likely an inflectionary ending.  See also modern verb 覚める (sameru), from earlier samu, where the final -u is an inflectionary ending.
Problematic.  Listed in Japanese sources as deriving from a compound of ara- ("newly appearing", from 生る (aru, “to come into being”)) + adjective-forming suffix -ta.
